Award.AwardTitle: Impacts of Metal-Ligand Interfacial Bonding Interactions on Nanoparticle Charge Transfer Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms Program supports Professor Shaowei Chen of the University of California-Santa Cruz in a project involving the synthesis and characterization of transition metal nanoparticles whose surface is capped by organic molecules covalently-bonded to the metal. The goal of the project is to provide increased understanding of electrical connectivity across the metal-organic junction in capped transition metal nanoparticles. To this end, a range of carbon-capped transition metal nanoparticles will be synthesized and studied in order to assess the effects of interfacial contacts, core size, and the structure of the organic ligand on nanoparticle electronic conductivity. These investigations will provide mechanistic insights into nanoparticle charge transfer dynamics that will impact a variety of applications including areas related to energy conversion, nanoelectronics, and catalysis.

This project, which combines chemistry and material science, will train graduate and undergraduate students in the techniques of nanoscience to include the synthesis, characterization and manipulation of nanoparticles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project is to develop new chemistry for nanoparticle surface functionalization and to study the impacts on the nanoparticle charge-transfer properties. Conventionally, metal nanoparticles are functionalized with thiol derivatives forming metal-sulfur (M-S) bonds by taking advantage of the strong affinity of thiol groups to metal surfaces. However, the M-S bonds lack interesting chemistry. In this project, we developed several new strategies for nanoparticle surface functionalization, forming metal-carbene (M=C) pi bonds, metal-acetylide (M-Csp) bonds, metal-vinylidene (M=C=CH-) bonds, as well as metal-nitrene (M=N) pi bonds. These metal-ligand bonds are highly conjugated in nature, leading to delocalization of electrons between particle-bound functional groups and hence the emergence of new optical and electronic properties. In essence, the functional groups behaved analogously to their dimeric counterparts. This offers a unique and powerful strategy in engineering the nanoparticle optical and electronic properties. A series of studies have been carried out during the duration of this project, demonstrating the unique applications of such nanoparticle systems in sensitive detection of volatile organic vapors as well as metal and nonmetal ions in solutions. Importantly, the unique metal-ligand interactions has also been found to impact the bonding interactions between the metal surfaces and reaction molecules in fuel cell electrochemistry, which may be exploited for the manipulation and enhancement of the nanoparticle electrocatalytic activity in fuel cell reactions.

 


Last Modified: 02/25/2015
Modified by: Shaowei Chen

Conventionally, metal nanoparticles are functionalized with thiol derivatives forming metal-sulfur (M-S) bonds by taking advantage of the strong affinity of thiol groups to metal surfaces. However, the M-S bonds lack interesting chemistry. These metal-ligand bonds are highly conjugated in nature, leading to delocalization of electrons between particle-bound functional groups and hence the emergence of new optical and electronic properties. In essence, the functional groups behaved analogously to their dimeric counterparts. This offers a unique and powerful strategy in engineering the nanoparticle optical and electronic properties. A series of studies have been carried out during the duration of this project, demonstrating the unique applications of such nanoparticle systems in sensitive detection of volatile organic vapors as well as metal and nonmetal ions in solutions. Importantly, the unique metal-ligand interactions has also been found to impact the bonding interactions between the metal surfaces and reaction molecules in fuel cell electrochemistry, which may be exploited for the manipulation and enhancement of the nanoparticle electrocatalytic activity in fuel cell reactions.
